success_criteria: alt attribute is missing in iframe or img tag

error_fixes.problem_type: alt attribute is missing in img tag
error_fixes.CoT:
To find the accessibility issue related to missing `alt` attributes in `img` tags, we need to:

1. Go through the HTML code and identify all `img` tags.
2. Check if each `img` tag has an `alt` attribute.
3. If any `img` tag is missing the `alt` attribute, then that would be the accessibility issue related to this rule.

Let's start by examining the HTML code for `img` tags and check for the presence of `alt` attributes.

success_criteria: input element or button is missing an associated label, it contains an alt attribute, or its label is empty

error_fixes.problem_type: input element or button is missing an associated label
error_fixes.offending_line: <input type="number" alt="quantity" id="quantity" name="quantity" min="1" required>
error_fixes.fixed_line: <label for="quantity">Number of Tickets:</label><input type="number" id="quantity" name="quantity" min="1" required>
error_fixes.CoT:
First, we need to identify input elements and buttons on the page. These are the elements that users can interact with, so it's important to ensure they have proper labels or associated text for screen readers. We will look for any inputs or buttons without appropriate labels. 

Let's start by checking each input element and button on the page for the mentioned issues. 

Here is the list of input elements and buttons on the page:
1. input with id="quantity"
2. input with id="name"
3. button with onclick="submitForm()" 

We will check each of these elements for the accessibility issues mentioned. Let's begin.

success_criteria: Audio or video element should avoid automatically playing audio
fixed_example:
<video controls>
<source src="bookstore-video.mp4" type="video/mp4">
Your browser does not support the video tag.
</video>

success_criteria: <b> <i> or <font> tag should not be used

error_fixes.fixed_line:
<label for="quantity" style="font-weight: bold;">
        Number of Tickets:
      </label>
error_fixes.CoT:
1. Look through the HTML code to identify any instances of the <b>, <i>, or <font> tags being used.

2. Check if any of these tags are being used for styling purposes.

3. If any of these tags are found, they should be replaced with appropriate semantic HTML elements or CSS styles.

4. Ensure that all styling is done using CSS and not inline styling with these tags.

Let's start by examining the HTML code for any instances of <b>, <i>, or <font> tags.

success_criteria: onmousedown event missing onkeydown event or script is not keyboard accessible

error_fixes.offending_line: <button type="button" onclick="submitForm()" style="background-color: #45a049;"> <!-- Adjusted background color for better contrast -->
error_fixes.fixed_line: <button type="button" onclick="submitForm" onkeydown="if(event.key === 'Enter') { submitForm(); }" style="background-color: #45a049;"> <!-- Adjusted background color for better contrast -->
error_fixes.CoT:
1. Look for any elements that have `onmousedown` event handlers but do not have corresponding `onkeydown` event handlers.
2. Verify if any of these elements or scripts are crucial for keyboard users to interact with the website effectively.
3. Identify any buttons or interactive elements that might require `onkeydown` event handling to ensure keyboard accessibility.
4. Ensure that keyboard users can perform the same actions and functionalities as mouse users on the website.

success_criteria: meta refresh with a time-out is used.

error_fixes.CoT:
Step 1: Identify the <marquee> element in the html
Step 2: Recognize that the <marquee> element is being used, which is not recommended for accessibility
Step 3: Provide an alternative solution for the scrolling effect without using the <marquee> element.

Sure, let's find the issue step by step:
1. Look for the `<title>` element in the HTML code.
2. Check if the `<title>` element has any text within it.
3. If the `<title>` element is empty, that would be the accessibility issue related to an empty title element.

Sure, let's break it down step by step to identify the problem with the anchor element:
1. Identify and locate the anchor elements in the HTML code.
2. Check if each anchor element contains text that is meaningful for screen readers and other assistive technologies.
3. If any anchor element does not have text content, that would be the issue we are looking for.

success_criteria: document language not identified or incorrect

error_fixes.problem_type: Document language not identified or incorrect
error_fixes.CoT:
1. Look for the <html> tag and check if it includes the lang attribute to specify the language of the document.
2. Ensure that the lang attribute is set to the correct language code (e.g., "en" for English).
3. If the lang attribute is missing or set to an incorrect value, update it accordingly to properly identify the document language.

success_criteria: input element has more than one associated label

error_fixes.problem_type: input element has more than one associated label
error_fixes.CoT:
To find the issue with the input element having more than one associated label, we need to:

1. Identify all the <label> elements in the form.
2. Check the "for" attribute of each <label> element to see which input element it is associated with.
3. Ensure that each input element is only associated with one <label> element.

Let's go through the code and check for any input elements that have more than one associated label.

success_criteria: element does not have complete start and end tags or id attribute is not unique

error_fixes.problem_type: element does not have complete start and end tags or id attribute is not unique
error_fixes.CoT:
Let's start by looking at the elements in the HTML code and check if they have complete start and end tags. This is important for accessibility because screen readers rely on correctly structured HTML to interpret the content.

I will also check if the `id` attributes are unique within the document, as having multiple elements with the same ID can cause issues for assistive technologies.
